comment.text: Phosphatase that acts on various phosphoinositides, including phosphatidylinositol 4-phosphate, phosphatidylinositol (4,5)-bisphosphate and phosphatidylinositol (3,4,5)-trisphosphate (PubMed:27435091). Has a role in clathrin-mediated endocytosis (By similarity). Hydrolyzes PIP2 bound to actin regulatory proteins resulting in the rearrangement of actin filaments downstream of tyrosine kinase and ASH/GRB2 (By similarity).
Interacts with ASH/GRB2. Interacts with PACSIN1, PACSIN2 and PACSIN3 (By similarity). Binds AMPH, SH3GL1, SH3GL2 and SH3GL3. Interacts with MYO1E (via SH3 domain).

Concentrated at clathrin-coated endocytic intermediates in nerve terminals. Isoform 1 is more enriched than isoform 2 in developing brain as well as non-neuronal cells. Isoform 2 is very abundant in nerve terminals.
Binds to EPS15 (a clathrin coat-associated protein) via a C-terminal domain containing three Asn-Pro-Phe (NPF) repeats.
The C-terminal proline-rich region mediates binding to a variety of SH3 domain-containing proteins including AMPH, SH3GL1, SH3GL2, SH3GL3 and GRB2.

disease.name: Parkinson disease 20, early-onset
disease.description: An early-onset form of Parkinson disease, a complex neurodegenerative disorder characterized by bradykinesia, resting tremor, muscular rigidity and postural instability, as well as by a clinically significant response to treatment with levodopa. The pathology involves the loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra and the presence of Lewy bodies (intraneuronal accumulations of aggregated proteins), in surviving neurons in various areas of the brain. PARK20 is characterized by young adult-onset of parkinsonism. Additional features may include seizures, cognitive decline, abnormal eye movements, and dystonia.

comment.text: The disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.

disease.name: Epileptic encephalopathy, early infantile, 53
disease.description: A form of epileptic encephalopathy, a heterogeneous group of severe childhood onset epilepsies characterized by refractory seizures, neurodevelopmental impairment, and poor prognosis. Development is normal prior to seizure onset, after which cognitive and motor delays become apparent. EIEE53 inheritance is autosomal recessive.

comment.text: The disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
In the central section; belongs to the inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate 5-phosphatase family.

property.value: Synthesis of PIPs at the plasma membrane
Synthesis of IP2, IP, and Ins in the cytosol
Synthesis of IP3 and IP4 in the cytosol

feature.description: In PARK20; impairs the phosphatase activity of the enzyme toward phosphatidylinositol-3-phosphate and phosphatidylinositol-4-phosphate.
In EIEE53; decreased inositol phosphate phosphatase activity.
Polymorphism; no effect on inositol phosphate phosphatase activity.
Polymorphism; no effect on inositol phosphate phosphatase activity.
In PARK20; unknown pathological significance; the patient also carries a heterozygous PINK1 truncating mutation.
